In response to Helen Robbins --

"How does having both parents in the work force drive down wages?"

It's called the law of supply and demand. It's one of several factors that drove down wages starting in the 70s.

What alternative universe do you live in? Where do you get the idea that two parents working is the cause of obesity and bad grades? How do you figure that having one salary is less risky than two? What if the one earner becomes sick and loses his/her job; then the family goes on welfare because the other parent has no work experience? Or the loss of that worker's health insurance means that the whole family is on the street because we don't have national health insurance. Exactly what is wrong with the US is that we don't have a social safety net which allows for broader choices for all members of society, not just men.

In response to Upstate Albert --

If you have two incomes and you live on one, then yes, you have a cushion if one person loses their job.

But a lot of two-income families max out their consumption to the point that they need both incomes to service the debt, in which case they haven't provided themselves much protection from the situation in which one person loses their job.

This is exactly what's wrong with the US: expecting women to be full-time workers while portraying housewives as bad women.

It would be a lot better if families had one parent be the bread winner, and the other parent stay home and nurture/raise their children. Having both parents in the workforce drives down wages, decentralizes families, puts families in riskier situations (becoming dependent on two incomes instead of one and one income earner gets sick) and causes tons of problems for children (obesity, bad grades, etc...). The primary breadwinner does not have to be the husband, however mother-nature has strong ways of indicating that women are nurturers while men are doers/workers.

Full employment is necessary for individual and national security. A high median and minimum standard of living will only result from such employment if the work done creates the material needs that define such standards. Laissez-faire advocates are convinced that all living standards suffer when full employment lowers fear of being fired and related high performance. If there were some proof of their convictions, modern automation and quality control more than overcome any such loss of job security. There is therefore no reason for less than full employment all the time. Moreover, if there is said to be a lack of money for the payrolls we need, such money shortage can be eliminated with output-based money when debt-based money is insufficient for universal full employment.

The two different surveys from the BLS are not painting the same picture of our employment situation. The CES establishment survey shows more than 1.2M added private sector jobs in the last six months, which is pretty decent job growth. The same survey shows non-farm payrolls expanding by 5.09% since the payroll bottom in Feb 2010. The CPS household survey shows employment expanding by only 3.92% since Feb 2010, which is barely enough to stay ahead of population growth.

Which survey is correct? At this time the two surveys are pointing in different policy directions - the CES job number indicates that we're making steady progress (though we need some increase in government jobs) while the CPS employment number says we're barely making any progress at all. We need to know which survey to trust and why. Where is Krugtron the Invincible?

Interesting article, but what James Atlas fails to mention is the reason why airlines increasingly cater to the "jet setter": global demand. And how does demand continue to outpace supply for these high priced seats: airline miles and loyalty perks.

I'm a budget traveler, but airline miles afforded me these luxuries:

- Upgrade to business class for me & Mom from SF to NYC (30,000 miles)
- 1 night stay at hotel near O'Hare to catch 6am flight (17,500 miles)
- RT from NYC to Vancouver (37,500 miles)
- 7 night hotel stay in Turks & Caicos (15,000 miles + $800) **I emptied out my miles bank

How did I incur so many miles? First, the airline ponies up 30,000 miles when you sign up. Second, pay for everything I do (bills, food shopping, restaurants) on my airline credit card. Third, you get miles when you fly the airline. Fourth, accumulate miles until you get to levels when you can trade them in. It may take a while, but its worth it.

Many of the folks in the pricey seats aren't rich at all - they just know how to take advantage of the system. Instead of complaining about the 1%, the 99% should realize how the 1% got so rich - by not paying for stuff.

"Although most Democrats are not Socialists, the Democratic party has many elements of Socialism in its core beliefs."

It is amazing how the right has managed to keep red-baiting alive in spite of all evidence to the contrary. The Soviet Union fell over twenty years ago. Socialism's moment has come and gone. There is no viable socialist movement in America. The Cold War is over. And Richard Nixon is dead, although his spirit lives on. The right has to create a phantom to rail against to divert attention from its own intellectual bankruptcy.

Nobody "creates a job". The entrepreneur provides an essential ingredient but his activities happen in the context of a collaboration or partnership with the entire society in which he or she lives. This society gave the entrepreneur birth, fed sheltered and clothed him when he was young and helpless, taught him to speak, read, write, and to understand numbers. Provided him with infrastructure, security against theft and violence. Provided laws and courts governing his contracts and protecting his ownership of property. For all that the society recognizes the central creative spark provided by the owner, for its services it still demands a certain ownership steak in whatever profits he realizes. Libertarians would give 90% ownership to the "job creator" and only 10% to society. Socialists would give the reverse. Most republicans would make something close to a 50-50 split. In addition however they would recognize that the owner is the only one in a position to really run and develop what he has created in the first place. They would thus keep him (or her) in full charge of operations and planning and have the government take a minimal backseat role by issuing regulations and making macroeconomic policy.

If low wage workers are so wonderful, then why don't their own countries want them? Mexico encourages its low wage workers to come here illegally. And yes, low wage labor does contribute to the economy no matter its nationality, which is why AMERICANS should be hired. ILlegal aliens displace Americans from jobs and burden the US taxpayer with subsidizing not only the unemployed American but the illegal alien.

Of course many Democrats are opposed to the suggested immigration reform. Although most Democrats are not Socialists, the Democratic party has many elements of Socialism in its core beliefs. the history of our immigration policy came from:
"Denis Kearney (1847–1907) was a California labor leader of the late 19th century who was known for his nativist and racist views about Chinese immigrants."

The labor movement has always objected to low skilled immigrants being able to come here at will.

On the other hand, the neo-conservative economists like Von Mises and Hayeck said that immigration laws were one of the major causes of wars, and that there is no such thing as American, or German, or Mexican jobs. Jobs belong to the people who create them and have the right to hire whom the wish. So we can see the hypocrisy of the Republicans, when they will not support Open immigration is a tenet of Libertarian economics. Immigration restrictions are by their nature part of Socialism.

I pointed out previously that low wage labor contributes to the economy, no matter the nationality of the workers. One commentator complained about how many $million U.S. dollars were sent back to Mexico, ignoring the $billions sent to Bangladesh and India. By his criteria, we should not travel to foreign countries either as we spend our money there.

During the housing boom, I did not hear of anyone saying they would not buy a house because some undocumented immigrant worked on it.

Kurt, if you can't find evidence for global warming on the internet, you're a denialist. (Note: the one newspaper article claiming no global warming in the past decade and a half quotes not one single climate scientist, and ignores all of the substantial warming of the oceans. It's not science, it's propaganda attempting to pose as science.)
You entirely ignore the fact that melting ice limits temperature rise and also the fact that the oceans are measurably acidifying. You are plainly dogmatically blind.

ARodney:

If you mean HYPE (about global warming), then indeed one need go no further than the mainstream media, the worldwide web or your local environmental activist headquarters.

However, if you truly want EVIDENCE (that late 20th Century warming was caused mainly by mankind, or dangerous, or irreversible, or responsible for weather extremes, etc.), you may be disappointed.

On the other hand, EVIDENCE for a STALL in atmospheric warming for the past decade - decade and a half is very strong, indeed. This is obvious to anyone capable of reading a graph.

http://tinyurl.com/pcnkwo8

The UK Met Office, a key promoter of Anthropogenic Global Warming, itself acknowledges the pause (while adhering to the dogma that warming is continuing nevertheless, albeit at a slower rate).

http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/research/news/alex-otto-article

You claim that skepticism is propaganda posing as science. IMHO, it's exactly the other way around. Loud proclamations, even if "agreed upon" by august societies, can not compete against data.

The data show clearly that average temperatures have risen by 1/3 or 1/4 of IPCC predictions and by about 1/2 of the lowest estimate referenced (ref. FAR WG II from 1990).

Look for yourself: Policymakers' summary (Page 1)
http://www.ipcc.ch/ipccreports/far/wg_II/ipcc_far_wg_II_full_report.pdf

I took that biaxin at 6 years old and swear to god I will never forget it. Gave me respect for medicine & the importance of sacrifice for healing sometimes.

ditch the bubblegum folks.

Wow, I didn't realize that spending an extra buck fifty at the pharmacy to get the medicine that tastes slightly unpleasant is "letting the kids run the show". I thought it was just being compassionate and considerate. Does this mean I should stop getting special flavors when I pick up medicines for my mom and grandma too?

"My kid will only take the bubblegum'? What a privileged bunch of hooey. How did kids take medicine before the advent of "cool flavors"?

When my daughter was in kindergarten, she had a severe case of Lyme disease. She was allergic to penicillin and too small for pills, so we were forced into our only option--Biaxin liquid, which is white and thick and smelly and has powdery chunks in it. It tasted like crap but it was the only way she was going to get better. So she took it for six months. No bubblegum. No arguments.

What do you think kids who need chemotherapy do? Does that come in a bubblegum flavor as well? Talk about knuckling under to your kids. C'mon guys, stop advocating your parental authority. It doesn't mean you're a fascist or abusive, it just means you're not letting your kids run the show.
Does your sister try to foist awful nicknames on other people, or just on lucky you?
Not so much we didn't care to as that we didn't dare to.
So what was the outcome of the "meeting?" Is this person on his way to doctorhood? Will he be "caring" for me or a member of my family? Or anyone in the world, for that matter?

It's not a rich/poor divide, but the divide is real. I've seen very wealthy people work hard to make sure their kids have opportunities to struggle and fail, to learn the value of money, and to learn that rules apply to all. I've also seen very poor people assume that poverty gives them the leeway to ignore the rules completely.
